Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium at the 2016 IEEE Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE 2016)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal will support U.S. Ph.D. students working in robotics the opportunity to share their knowledge and interact with each other and more senior researchers, to learn about different sub-fields within robotics, to meet potential employers, and to become apprised of new technology that will be demonstrated by vendors. This goal will be accomplished by partially supporting the travel costs for U.S. Ph.D. students to attend the International Conference on Automation Science and Engineering, which is one of the flagship conferences of the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society. The conference attracts an international crowd that includes academics, industry workers, entrepreneurs, and funding agency leaders.

Institution.Name: University of Louisville Research Foundation Inc

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the travel of 11 US-Bound Doctoral Students to the 2016 IEEE Conference on Automation Science and Engineering (CASE) and the 2016 IEEE International Symposium on Assembly and Manufacturing, events held in Fort Worth, Texas in August 2016.

IEEE-CASE conference is a flagship event of the Robotics and Automation Society of IEEE, focusing on automation sciences and engineering. In 2016, the event attracted nearly 500 participants from around the globe. Between August 21 and 24, nearly 300 papers were presented, along with 10 workshops and tutorials, a poster session, and 5 plenary speakers were invited. More than 100 students participated in this event, including the 11 recipients of this Doctoral Consortium Award. 

Each selected doctoral student received a travel grant of $500, administered through the University of Louisville, the home institution of the Principal Investigator. Applicants were selected by a committee composed of 5 faculty organizers of the conference, based on clearly defined merit criteria. Recipients were required to present a paper at the conference, participate in a Doctoral Consortium meeting, and Poster Session, and submit an experience report after the conference. The students and organizers met on August 22 and presented their research.

One of the recipient students won the Best Paper Award at the conference. Overall, this grant was instrumented in encouraging student participation in this important event for the IEEE Robotics and Automation Society.


Last Modified: 10/23/2017
Modified by: Dan O Popa
